ygData.subject: New Paper Comparing a New Encoding to HyperNEAT w.r.t. Network Properties (modularity, scale-free, regularity, scalability, etc.)
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all- I am pleased to announce a paper by Marcin Suchorzewski and myself that describes a new generative encoding called the Developmental Symbolic

Subject: New Paper Comparing a New Encoding to HyperNEAT w.r.t. Network
 Properties (modularity, scale-free, regularity, scalability, etc.)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=467342474; y=Si91TWRV5kX-PF3MhM3wxqGS1hPi9yBCH3FXHxRD3UOp7Zs8RHoi

Content-type: text/plain;
	charset="ISO-8859-1"
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

Hello all-

I am pleased to announce a paper by Marcin Suchorzewski and mys=
elf that
describes a new generative encoding called the Developmental Symbo=
lic
Encoding (DSE). 

DSE combines a key innovation from HyperNEAT (making =
phenotypic properties a
function of their geometric location) with an encod=
ing inspired by Cellular
Encoding.  We investigate whether the types of neu=
ral networks produced by
HyperNEAT are different from those produced by DSE=
 (an iterative,
growth-based encoding). Specifically, we compare DSE to Hyp=
erNEAT with
respect to each encoding's tendency to produce networks that ar=
e modular,
regular, scale-free, and scalable. In general, we find that DSE =
produced
networks that were more modular and scale-free than HyperNEAT. We =
also found
that DSE outperformed HyperNEAT on a pattern-recognition problem=
.

I think you'll enjoy looking at the visualizations of the networks evolv=
ed
by DSE and HyperNEAT, and noting their differences. Overall, I think thi=
s
work raises interesting questions as to what types of encodings produce w=
hat
types of network properties. For example, are iterative growth/rewrite
=
encodings more likely to produce modular networks? Does HyperNEAT need
grow=
th or recursion to increase its modularity? Etc. What do you think?

The DS=
E encoding is also an interesting and promising encoding in its own
right. =


Here is a link to the paper and the abstract:

https://www.msu.edu/~jclun=
e/webfiles/publications/2011-SuchorzewskiAndClune-
DSE-Gecco.pdf


A Novel =
Generative Encoding for Evolving Modular, Regular and Scalable
Networks

Su=
chorzewski M and Clune J. To appear in the Proceedings of the Genetic and
E=
volutionary Computation Conference.  2011.



Abstract: In this paper we in=
troduce the Developmental Symbolic Encoding
(DSE), a new generative encodin=
g for evolving networks (e.g. neural or
boolean). DSE combines elements of =
two powerful generative encodings,
Cellular Encoding and HyperNEAT, in orde=
r to evolve networks that are
modular, regular, scale-free, and scalable. G=
enerating networks with these
properties is important because they can enha=
nce performance and
evolvability. We test DSE=B9s ability to generate scale=
-free and modular
networks by explicitly rewarding these properties and see=
ing whether
evolution can produce networks that possess them. We compare th=
e networks
DSE evolves to those of HyperNEAT. The results show that both en=
codings can
produce scale-free networks, although DSE performs slightly, bu=
t
significantly, better on this objective. DSE networks are far more modula=
r
than HyperNEAT networks. Both encodings produce regular networks. We furt=
her
demonstrate that individual DSE genomes during development can scale up=
 a
network pattern to accommodate different numbers of inputs. We also comp=
are
DSE to HyperNEAT on a pattern recognition problem. DSE significantly
ou=
tperforms HyperNEAT, suggesting that its potential lay not just in the
prop=
erties of the networks it produces, but also because it can compete with
le=
ading encodings at solving challenging problems. These preliminary results
=
imply that DSE is an interesting new encoding worthy of additional study.
T=
he results also raise questions about which network properties are more
lik=
ely to be produced by different types of generative encodings.



PS. Becau=
se there is not a current working distribution of Cellular
Encoding, this e=
ncoding can serve as a descendent of CE if people wish to
compare against t=
his type of encoding. We'd be happy to make the code
available. 

Best rega=
rds,
Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Creative Machines Laborat=
ory
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune



--B_3386460613_11311031

spect to each encoding's tendency to produce networks that are modular, reg=
ular, scale-free, and scalable. In general, we find that DSE produced netwo=
rks that were more modular and scale-free than HyperNEAT. We also found tha=
t DSE outperformed HyperNEAT on a pattern-recognition problem. </div><=

ize=3D"4"><span class=3D"Apple-style-span" style=3D"font-size: 14px;">Abstr=
act: In this paper we introduce the Developmental Symbolic Encoding (D=
SE), a new generative encoding for evolving networks (e.g. neural or boolea=
n). DSE combines elements of two powerful generative encodings, Cellular En=
coding and HyperNEAT, in order to evolve networks that are modular, regular=
, scale-free, and scalable. Generating networks with these properties is im=
portant because they can enhance performance and evolvability. We test DSE&=
#8217;s ability to generate scale-free and modular networks by explicitly r=
ewarding these properties and seeing whether evolution can produce networks=
 that possess them. We compare the networks DSE evolves to those of HyperNE=
AT. The results show that both encodings can produce scale-free networks, a=
lthough DSE performs slightly, but significantly, better on this objective.=
 DSE networks are far more modular than HyperNEAT networks. Both encodings =
produce regular networks. We further demonstrate that individual DSE genome=
s during development can scale up a network pattern to accommodate differen=
t numbers of inputs. We also compare DSE to HyperNEAT on a pattern recognit=
ion problem. DSE significantly outperforms HyperNEAT, suggesting that its p=
otential lay not just in the properties of the networks it produces, but al=
so because it can compete with leading encodings at solving challenging pro=
blems. These preliminary results imply that DSE is an interesting new encod=
ing worthy of additional study. The results also raise questions about whic=
h network properties are more likely to be produced by different types of g=
enerative encodings.</span></font></p></div><div><br></div><div><br></div><=

r Encoding, this encoding can serve as a descendent of CE if people wish to=
